TopicTitle: How are your Kerbals handling the Kerpocalypse???

Articles.Content:
Upon recent study of ancient Kayan calendars. Kerbal conspiracy theorists have surmised the end of the .23.5 world fast approaching. As a result Kerbal kind is responding in a variety of ways. The following Kerbals of the Sub-Standard rocket program are proceeding with an emergency mad dash to return all Kerbals home to be with their families before the .24 end of the world. Anyway, a long story short I'm just curious what you guys are winding down before .24. Here are some examples of my mad rush.

The Lunar colony is the first to run for home after planting a flag.

Bill Kerman unwisely takes the rover in the background and decides the "drive" home from Minimus ranch ending up in a goofy Kerbal orbit.

Doctor Banner arrives with just enough to push Bill into a low orbit before landing himself.

Various items from different programs are cobbled together to send rescue teams to the Jool system. (General Landers, Tylo descent modules, Ion Tugs, and even "Angry Rover"

The general lander below can act as a bare minimum ssto with A jet engine to hit an 80x80 orbit or becomes an excellent lander by substituting a rocket engine.

Bill Kermans descent back home gets way iffy....

Bill Kerman survives Sans parachutes in the incredibly tough rover below with his rocket impacting at 100 meters per second.

You've motivated me to bring my Kerbals home for 0.24... Good thing I only have two out there.
Same deal here. I have a lot more up there though. And some ships and stations that can't be landed practically. But I may try to at least bring home all the Kerbals.
I was going to nuke my 0.23.5 career save and start over, but since ScienceTM mode is a thing I'm now going to port it over to that and play it when the fancy strikes.
Mine don't know how to read nor write, so they're safe from the abomination of contracts. Hooray for illiteration.

Mine are mostly exploding and going about their daily business.

Why would kerbals care about the end of the world, their going to die on my rockets eventually anyway.

Mine are mostly exploding and going about their daily business.

Why would kerbals care about the end of the world, their going to die on my rockets eventually anyway.

Because they're rather die in an explosion caused by the misfiring of a rocket thruster than in the death of the universe, obviously

Well, unless of course the end of the universe involved explosions beyond the imaginative capacity of any Kerbal, in which case they'd probably like that more...but that would imply that your hard drive just exploded spectacularly or something.

Kerpocalypse, I like that. But it won't be anything spectacular or hilarious. Kerbol, along with all the planets and moons will be simply - gone - from one second to another.

Just to magically reappear in a parallel universe a few seconds later.

No regrets to leave it all behind. What remains are a lot of good memories and a lot of knowledge.

Waiting, and playing Minecraft. My kerbals of 10 seperate saves are whining. One is stuck on RRS kerbin, the other on gilly, 22 of em,

If I tried to rescue em all, my save game would corrupt due to not having the correct mods

Bringing them home? I still have to send more out in .23.5 !

At least five will go to Jool this evening and maybe three are scribbling a Duna Revisited mission in the cantina right now!

But in the end they will all be back at KSC.
I forgot i had TAC life support enabled when i was time warping a probe to Eeloo 5 weeks ago. so yeah their aren't any left

Just recovered all kerbals from all space stations in the Kerbol System using one mothership. It was almost a grand tour, except there were none to recover from Moho or Eeloo...

All stations are abandoned. Recovery teams will be sent out ASAP if anyone survies the Kerpocalypse...

Okay, over dramaticness over. Carry on.

I started a save some time ago. It only has a three Kerbal stations in orbit (One orbital assembly facility, one large fuel depot, and one free-flying space laboratory with its own propulsion) amounting to around 20 Kerbals in space. but multiple Kerbal space shuttles in orbit and ships around the Mun, where I just recently established a twelve Kerbal outpost. In interplanetary space, we have a large ship on a outbound Hohmann Transfer to Duna and a crew working on the Dunaian surface. There is a asteroid tug with a crew of two heading toward Kerbin, but it already has a shuttle awaiting to pick them up in LKO, so they should be fine. Otherwise, it's mostly probes and rovers for the rest of the system.

My rescue plans are as follows.

STS-78, STS-80, and STS-81 are in orbit. STS-78 will assist in the evacuation of Space Station Liberty (The assembly facilty), but will only be able to bring three astronauts home of the ten onboard. STS-82 and the two Soyuz escape pods onboard (Liberty earned the nickname of "Titanic" by having not enough escape pods for the whole crew) will bring the rest of the crews home. STS-80 is awaiting the arrival of the asteroid tug, and STS-81 is working on repairing the Kerman Space Telescope. STS-81 is to halt all repair work immediately and bring the telescope back into its payload bay to be returned to KSC. STS-80 is to await the arrival of the tug and evacuate the crew immediately back to Kerbin.

Onboard the fuel depot (Space Station Polaris), the crew should easily escape through the Soyuz escape pods (As the station operates on a skeleton crew), but the free-flying laboratory will require a full extraction by the shuttle (With the return of the station to KSC if possible). As for the crew on Duna, they should escape just fine to their cruiser and return home, as they were to anyway. For the outbound crew, it would be slightly more difficult, and probably a couple tears over the cancelled landing and surface mission, but they will return home for extraction by the shuttle. STS-85 and 86 will take part in rescuing the crews. On the Mun base, they already have a tug in orbit and two ascent vehicles, so they should be OK in returning home as long as a shuttle takes them on. STS-84, STS-87, and STS-89 will aid in their rescue. STS-88 will conduct the some more Spacelab research (Since the stations have been evacuated).

If they survive, all stations and bases will be restored to full operation.
Return to home, rescue... umm no. My 23.5 universe has already ended, they never saw it coming.
